bibl.title: Letter from [James E. Peabody] to Clara, Richard, and George [Peabody?], December 29, 1929

div1.p: [Peabody] describes his trips related to his campaign to honor the yellow fever heroes through an Act of Congress.

div1.head: Letter from [James E. Peabody] to Clara, Richard, and George [Peabody?], December 29, 1929
div1.p:
Betty reached home last night at 10:30, and we were indeed glad
to see her. So you see this letter is addressed to the rest of our
far-away children. We had much to talk about, and so we did not get to
bed until after midnight. But we made up for it this morning, for
breakfast was served for the two of us at 9 o'clock, and Betty had here
in season to go to church with us. We went up to the First Congrega-
tional Church in Hewton Center, and heard dear old Dr. Noyes preach
his last sermon on The Christmas Angels. He has been here for 35 years.
They gave him $26,600 as a parting gift, and made him Pastor Emeritus
without duties. The church was founded in 1664, and in the 265 years
of its history it has had only 10 Pastors. Dr. Noyes goes to Baytonia
Beach, Florida to take charge of the Tourists' Church. That's the way
to retire, I'll tell the woirld.

I suppose before this you have received my postal from Washington.
After my nine lectures on Yellow Fever and on Flies and Mosquitoes Mother
thought a sea trip to Baltimore would be a good thing for me, and it
certainly was. I ate, and slept, and loafed the three days on the boat.
I had a wonderful time with the Big Four Doctors in Baltimore who helped
so much in getting the Yellow Fever Bill through Congress. I got well
acqainted with Dr. Oliver, visited his office in the Criminal Courts
Building, his Professional Office, Homewood, where he lives with the
Johns Hopkins students, and attended the Anglican (High Episcopalian)
Mass with him on Sunday morning. He is certainly a wonderful man.

Dr. Welch urged me to go on to Washington to see Secretary Mellon
of the Treasury Department relative to the gold medals that are to be
given to the 22 heroes next year. He was most cordial, and promised to
make it his special interest to secure a wonderful piece of work. I
had the good fortune to talk with Sec. Wilbur of the Interior Depart-
ment, Surgeon General Ireland of the War Department, Surgeon General
Cumming of the Public Health Service, Senators Copeland of New York and
Senator Walsh of Mass., Congressmen Wainwright and Davenport of New
York, Mrs. Rogers, Representative from Mass., Col. Kean, Mrs. Walter
Reed and her beautiful Daughter, Blossom, and many others. I lectured
for an hour and a half to a fine room-full of boys and girls in the
big HoKinley High School in Washington, with Col. Kean present. He
was in Cuba when the wonderful work was done in 1900, he gave me a few
minor criticisms, and told me it was remarkable that a group of high
school students would listen for 90 minutes to any lecture. Telegrams
and letters called me to New York. Hunt and I begin work on the four
books very soon. He takes a Sabbatical next term.

G. W. failed us on letter, but our ever faithful Dick is always on
the job. Those Ithaca pictures are great! Hope there are more.

Perhaps you can read these if you place them over
a sheet of white paper. Je Do not return
